prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.label.name: ยง
head.headtext: Public Interest in the Administration of Justice

para.paratext: The courts will generally order the production of confidential information where it is the subject-matter of a lawsuit, unless the party resisting disclosure can establish that:
disclosure would result in a serious risk to an important interest, and
the beneficial risks of preventing disclosure would outweigh the adverse effects.[1]
The onus is on the party resisting disclosure to establish why there should be no disclosure.[2]
Anadarko Canada Corp. v. Gibson Petroleum Co. (2004), 31 Alta. L.R. (4th) 229 (C.A.).

Aventis Pasteur v. Canada (Attorney General) (2004), 38 C.P.R. (4th) 164 (F.C.T.D.). See also Business Depot Ltd. v. 2502731 Nova Scotia Ltd. (2004), 131 A.C.W.S. (3d) 14 (N.S.C.A.), where confidential information relating to Staples' business was not ordered to be produced, as the court accepted that Staples would suffer irreparable harm if the information had to be produced. However, see also Cadillac Fairview Corp. v. Standard Parking of Canada Ltd. (2004), 50 C.P.C. (5th) 72 (Ont. S.C.J.), where the court found that correctly disposing of the litigation by disclosing the identity of the informants outweighed the benefit served by protecting the identities of the informants.
